questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. The medical officer on duty takes his dying declaration as he feels that the patient's death is imminent. In India, this dying declaration is accepted under?
questions.solution:
In India, the dying declaration is accepted under IEA section 32.

Procedure:

  • As soon the severely injured person is brought to the hospital, the medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded. Fitness of the declarant to make the statement should be examined first.
  • The doctor can record it himself or herself if he thinks that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. In such a case, the police or the doctor concerned must note down the reason as to why waiting for the magistrate for recording this statement was not feasible.
  • Treatment should not be delayed while recording dying declaration.
  • The doctor has to ascertain that the person is of sound mind (compos mentis).
  • If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained upto that point.
  • Usually recorded in the form of a simple narrative in the patient's own language.
  • No suggestions, prompting, help, or leading questions from other people is allowed.
  • No outsider is allowed to be present
  • After completing writting, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it by signing/thumb impression. Signature of two witnesses is also mandatory.

Other options:

  • IEA section 139: Cross-examination of a witness
  • IEA section 114 A: Doctrine of Adverse Inference: When a rape victim states that she did not consent, the presumption is usually in her favor.
  • IEA section 45: Expert witness.

questions.text: A doctor destroying a sample of gastric lavage in a poisoning case is punishable under_____
questions.solution:
A doctor destroying a sample of gastric lavage in a poisoning case is punishable under Section 201 of IPC.

Section 201 of IPC: Provides punishment for causing the disappearance of evidence of offense (e.g., destroying a sample of gastric lavage, clothing carrying evidence of poison, etc.)

Other options:

  • Section 176 of IPC: Provides punishment for omission to give notice or information (including that of a poisoning case) to the public servant/police.
  • Section 177 of IPC: Provides punishment for furnishing false information (including that of a poisoning case).
  • Section 202 of IPC: Provides punishment for intentional concealment of information of offense (including that of a poisoning case).

questions.text:
A police sub-inspector brings the accused in a rape case to a doctor and requests a medical examination. He believes that examination findings would yield evidence to prove the offense allegedly committed. However, the accused is not cooperative. Under which section of BNSS (CrPC) can the doctor examine the accused?

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The doctor can examine the accused using force under section 52 BNSS (Section 53 CrPC) as requested by the sub-inspector.

Section 52 BNSS (Section 53-A CrPC) states that when a person is arrested for rape or attempted rape, and there is a reasonable belief that examining their body could provide evidence of the crime, a registered medical practitioner (RMP) employed by a government or local authority hospital is permitted to conduct the examination. If such a practitioner is not available within a 16-kilometre radius of the crime scene, any other RMP can perform the examination at the request of a police officer. The practitioner, along with anyone assisting them in good faith and under their direction, is allowed to use necessary and reasonable force to carry out the examination.

Other options:

Option A: Section 337 BNSS (300 CrPC) - Person once convicted or acquitted not to be tried for the same offence.

Option B: Section 184 BNSS (164A CrPC) deals with the examination of the victim of rape by a medical expert with the consent of the woman or of a person competent to give such consent.

Option D: Section 53 BNSS (54 CrPC): Examination of arrested person by a medical officer. When any person is arrested, he shall be examined by a medical officer in the service of the Central Government or a State Government.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male consumes alcohol by his own will from a bar. When he returns home, his father questions him regarding his alcohol addiction. The man gets agitated and assaults his father. Which among the following IPC sections render the son responsible for his actions?
questions.solution:
In this situation, the son is responsible for his actions according to IPC section 86.

A person who under voluntary intoxication commits an act is liable for the act according to IPC section 86.

IPC Section 84 states that the act of a person of an unsound mind is not liable for punishment/prosecution. Also, known as the McNaughten's Rule, the IPC states that, ''Nothing is an offense which is done by a person who, at the time of doing it, by reason of unsoundness of mind, is incapable of knowing the nature of the act, or that he is doing what is either wrong or contrary to law''. 

The defense under this section requires the following elements to be established:

(i) The accused was suffering from unsoundness of mind at the time of doing the act.

(ii) The accused was incapable of knowing the nature of the act or that he was doing what was either wrong or contrary to law.

The correct match is

questions.text:
A 20-year-old man likes a female television anchor and follows her on all her social media accounts. He tries to speak to her several times while she goes for a morning jog and messages her multiple times on social media. She warns him to stop following her, but he ignores it and continues with such behavior. Under which IPC section can the female anchor lodge a complaint?

IPC - Indian penal code
questions.solution:
The anchor lodges a complaint under the IPC section 354-D. This section deals with stalking.

Under this section, stalking is defined as whoever follows a woman and contacts or tries to contact such woman to make personal interaction repeatedly, despite the woman showing clear disinterest or monitors the internet usage, e-mail or any other electronic mode of communication of that woman.

Section 354 IPC- Lays down punishment for assault or criminal force to a woman with intent to outrage her modesty. Punishment includes imprisonment of 1-5 years and a fine.

The subsections include:

  • 354A– Sexual harassment in the form of physical contact or sexual gestures, request or demand for sexual favours, making sexual remarks, and showing pornography. Punishment includes imprisonment of 1-5 years or fine or both
  • 354B– Assault or criminal force on a female with intent to disrobe her. Punishment includes imprisonment of 3-7 years and a fine.
  • 354C– Voyeurism: One who observes an unsuspecting person who is naked, disrobing or engaging in sexual activity in order to attain sexual gratification. Punishment for the first offence is imprisonment of 1-3 years and a fine. Punishment for subsequent offences includes imprisonment of 3-7 years.
  • 354D– Stalking. Punishment includes imprisonment up to 3 years and a fine.

questions.text: Which of the following IPC sections is not related to grievous injury?
questions.solution:
IPC Section 319 defines hurt (not grievous hurt) that includes bodily pain, infirmity, or disease caused to any individual.

Grievous hurt or injury is defined to include injuries such as emasculation, permanent damage to eyesight (either eye), permanent damage to hearing (either ear), damage to any member or joint, destruction or permanent impairment of the power of any member or joint, permanent disfigurement of the head or face, fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth, and any hurt that endangers the victim's life or causes them severe bodily pain, thereby impairing their ability to follow their daily routine for a period of 20 days. 

Other options:

  • Section 320 - Defines grievous hurt
  • Section 326 - Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by a dangerous weapon (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Section 331: Causing grievous hurt to extort confession (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine) or to compel restoration of property.

Other IPC sections related to grievous hurt:

  • Sec 322: Voluntary causation of grievous hurt.
  • Sec 325: Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt (imprisonment up to 7 years with fine)
  • Sec 329: Causing grievous hurt to extort property (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 333: Causing hurt to deter public servant from the duty (imprisonment up to 10 years with fine)
  • Sec 335: Causing grievous hurt on grave or sudden provocations (imprisonment with 4 years + or –fine)
  • Sec 338: Causing grievous hurt by act endangering life/safety of others (imprisonment with 2 years + or –fine)

questions.text: A husband keeps demanding property from his wife which belongs to her ancestors. When she refused, she was physically hurt by him. Under which section of IPC would he be punished?
questions.solution:
The husband shall be punished under Section 498A of IPC.

The husband or relatives of the husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty (including dowry harassment) shall be punished with imprisonment for a term that may extend to 3 years and shall be liable to a fine.

  1. Any willful conduct that is of such a nature as is likely to drive a woman to commit suicide or to cause grave injury or danger to her life, limb, or health (whether mental or physical) or

  2. Harassment of a woman where such harassment is with a view to coercing her or any person related to her, to meet any unlawful demand for any property or valuable security or on account of failure by her or any person related to her to meet such demand.

Other options:

  • IPC 304B - This legal provision comes into effect when the death of a woman occurs by burns/bodily injury or any cause apart from normal circumstances within the first 7 years of her marriage. Evidence of cruelty or harassment by her spouse or relatives of her spouse in connection with demands for dowry must be shown. An individual accused of dowry death (cognizable, non-bailable) is liable to imprisonment from 10 years to life. 
  • IPC 509 Word, gesture, or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman shall be punished with simple imprisonment for a term that may extend to 1 year, with a fine, or with both.
  • IPC 113A - Presumption as to abutment of suicide by a married woman. The Court may presume that the suicide of a married woman had been abetted by her husband or by relatives of her husband when it is shown that she had committed suicide within a period of seven years from the date of her marriage and that her husband or such relative of her husband had subjected her to cruelty.

questions.text:
A mother who had given birth to a female child flees with her husband late at night, leaving the baby behind at the hospital. This act is punishable under which section of the IPC?

IPC: Indian penal code
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts an act with the intention of abandoning a child who is under the age of 12 years, which is a punishable offense under Section 317 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).

Section 317 of the IPC states that if the father or mother or anyone having the care of a child under the age of twelve years, leaves the child in any place with the intention of abandoning the child, they shall be punished with imprisonment up to seven years even more so for a term. The punishment may extend to ten years if the child so exposed or abandoned is a girl child. They may also be asked to pay a fine of up to 1 lakh rupees.

In India, infanticide is considered murder, and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Option C: IPC 316 – Causing the death of a quick unborn child (fetus whose movements can be felt) by any act amounts to culpable homicide. Punishment can be up to ten years imprisonment. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 2 lakh rupees.

Option D: IPC 315 – This section covers a person doing an act intended to prevent the child from being born alive or to cause it to die after its birth. They are punished with imprisonment for up to 7 years. If it is performed after a test confirming the gender of the fetus to be female, they may be punished with imprisonment for life and a fine of 1 lakh rupees.

Option A: Section 318 IPC – It deals with concealment of birth.

questions.text:
An alleged female convict is arrested for a crime she did not commit. She was tortured by the investigating officer and was raped by him in police custody. Under which section will the inquest be done in this scenario?

IPC - Indian Penal Code

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
The given scenario is indicative of custodial rape. A magistrate inquest is done under BNSS Section 196 (Section 176 CrPC).

Custodial rape is defined as the offence committed by persons who are in supervisory positions indulging in sexual intercourse with women in their custody by inducing or seducing the woman by taking advantage of his official position.

BNSS 196 (Section 176 CrPC) deals with magistrate inquest in which the cause of death is not under natural circumstances. Magistrate inquest may be conducted by the District Magistrate, Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Tahsildar, or any other Executive Magistrate empowered by the State Government.

Indications for Magistrate Inquest:

  • Custodial rape
  • Death in police custody or police interrogation
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, Borstal school
  • Death in a psychiatric hospital
  • Dowry death
  • Cases of exhumation.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Section 63 (Section 375 IPC)deals with the definition of rape. In BNS 63, the Age of Consent of 15 years is replaced by 18 years in BNS. Exception 2 of Section 63 states that “sexual intercourse or acts by a man with his wife, the wife not being under 18 years of age, is not rape”.

Option B- BNS Section 68 (Section 376 IPC) deals with the punishment of rape by a person in authority. It is termed custodial rape.

Option D- BNSS Section 194 (Section 174 CrPC) deals with the police inquest. It is done in suicide, homicide, killing by any animal or machinery or accident, and death under circumstances that raise suspicion of another person committing the offence.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines the punishment for attempting to throw acid?
questions.solution:
Section 326B of IPC deals with voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid. Punishment is imprisonment of not less than five years with a fine.

Punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt by the use of acid is defined under section 326A of IPC.

questions.text: Which section of IPC defines injury?
questions.solution:
The definition of injury is given by section 44 of IPC.

It states that the word “injury” denotes any harm whatever ille­gally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation, or proper­ty.

Other options:

  • Section 46 of IPC - Death denotes the death of a human being.
  • Section 319 of IPC - Hurt means bodily pain, disease, or infirmity caused to any person. It does not include mental pain.
  • Section 320 of IPC - Defines grievous hurt.
